s.text: The Cambridge delivers a smoother, more coherent, more rhythmic, more dynamic, more tonally true picture of the music.
His Bose 901 loudspeakers, the company's premium line for 30 years, have nine speaker cones, positioned all over the cabinet, so that the sound bounces around your room "just like in a concert hall."
How do these radios eke such relatively big sounds out of such small boxes?

His methods also encourage high prices: The 901s cost $1,400 a pair (some companies make $300 speakers that sound better) because nine cones cost more than two or three; the Wave radio costs $350 because that 7 foot tube was a bear to design.
The frequency of a sound wave is defined by its length: The longer the wave, the deeper the bass.

His methods also encourage high prices: The 901s cost $1,400 a pair (some companies make $300 speakers that sound better) because nine cones cost more than two or three; the Wave radio costs $350 because that 7 foot tube was a bear to design.

He applied 47 years of experience with this art to the rather skimpy components of the Model 88, which explains how he gets such a smooth, coherent sound from not only a small box but also a cheap one.
Such a little thing--barely the size of a shoe box--yet it puts out the "full, rich sound" of a "primary music system."

His methods also encourage high prices: The 901s cost $1,400 a pair (some companies make $300 speakers that sound better) because nine cones cost more than two or three; the Wave radio costs $350 because that 7 foot tube was a bear to design.
Such a long tube gives sound waves lots of room to enlarge.

His methods also encourage high prices: The 901s cost $1,400 a pair (some companies make $300 speakers that sound better) because nine cones cost more than two or three; the Wave radio costs $350 because that 7 foot tube was a bear to design.

One problem, among many, is that most people's living rooms aren't Carnegie Hall; as a result, the music just sounds muddy.

And though the Bose hit the low octaves of the acoustic bass, the Cambridge caught the finger-pluckings of the bass strings.
But just this month, what may be the best tabletop radio hit the market.
Such a little thing--barely the size of a shoe box--yet it puts out the "full, rich sound" of a "primary music system."
In the back of the speakers is a 7 foot tube that has been folded into a thin, tight maze to fit inside the radio box.

Those familiar with the Gorecki know that, on some full-size (if not very good) stereo systems, the first minute or so--bass violins growling quietly--comes off as a vague rumble, its melody barely audible.
